results.title: Narritjin Maymuru
results.creator_credit: Philip Robertson, Ian Dunlop and Film Australia
results.brief_description: Narritjin Maymuru is a respected aboriginal artist. This series of films profiles the man and his work, as well as looking at the traditional way of life he and his family follow at Djarrakpi near Yirrkala in the Northern Territory. Photography is by Dean Semler.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Philip Robertson, Ian Dunlop and Film Australia

group_works.title: At the canoe camp
group_works.creator_credit: Philip Robertson, Ian Dunlop and Film Australia

results.title: Narritjin at Djarrakpi. Part 1
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Narritjin Maymuru (A)”.
Narritjin Maymuru and his family are establishing a small settlement at Djarrakpi, an important Manggalili clan site on the northern head of Blue Mud Bay in the Northern Territory. Narritjin is a renowned artist and he and his family produce bark paintings and craft work to sell at Yirrkala. This program, together with Part 2 [507335], gives an insight into Narritjin’s family life and, through his paintings, his role as an educator, teaching his sons about their clan land and its ancestral history.

results.title: At the canoe camp
results.creator_credit: Philip Robertson, Ian Dunlop and Film Australia
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Narritjin Maymuru (A)”.
Narritjin Maymuru is leader of the Manggalili clan of northeast Arnhem Land. Covers the daily life of Narritjin and his family at a camp in the bush. Shows the making of dug out canoes. Photography by Dean Semler.

results.title: At the crossroads: the story of America's endangered species
results.creator_credit: Marty Stouffer, Mark Stouffer and Stouffer Productions
results.brief_description: Much of America’s wildlife is now endangered because of hunting, trapping, poisoning, habitat destruction and environmental pollution. America’s extinct mammals and birds include the Gull Island Vole, the Plains Wolf, the Sea Mink, the Labrador Duck and the Great Auk. the Whooping Crane are a dramatic example of an endangered species which came back form the brink of extinction. A simple alternative is offered and some important reasons why these endangered species are vitally important to all life on Earth are presented. Includes footage of the Ivory-billed Woodpecker which was last filmed in 1935 and is probably now extinct. Narrated by Barton Heyman.

results.title: At the circus
results.creator_credit: Edward Buzzell, Mervyn LeRoy and Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer
results.brief_description: A shyster lawyer and two incompetents save a circus from bankruptcy while a man-eating gorilla and the combined unmistakable talents of a tattooed lady and a crazy musical conductor move the plot foward at a furious pace. Blending all that is ridiculous and crazy this movie is one of the Marx Bros classics. Cast also includes Eve Arden, Margaret Dumont, Nat Pendleton, Fritz Feld.

results.title: At play in the fields of the Lord
results.creator_credit: Hector Babenco, Saul Zaentz and Saul Zaentz Company
results.brief_description: Tom Berenger, Daryl Hannah and Aidan Quinn star in a powerful story of mercenaries, missionaries and a tribe of primitive Indians who clash in fanatical conflict in the remote and unforgiving forest of Amazonia. A tragic chain of events is set in motion when the modern world intrudes on the rainforest and its indigenous people. Shot entirely on location in the Amazon forest.

results.title: At long last
results.creator_credit: John Ralph, Dennis Sawyer and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: A guided tour through the interior and behind the scenes of the new National Library of Canada in Ottawa showing modern devices for information storage and retrieval - teletype, computers, microfilm and an exhaustive card catalogue.

results.title: Asylum
results.creator_credit: Roy Baker, Milton Subotsky, Max J Rosenberg, Amicus Productions and Harbour productions
results.brief_description: Are the patients incurably insane or just part of the occult? A young psychiatric doctor (Robert Powell) visits an asylum where he is to have a short residency. Upon arriving he finds out the director/leading doctor has now become a patient and is upstairs with the other sick people. There are four patients and the young doctor is to guess which of the patients is the now mad Dr B. Starr and in doing so, will get to keep the job. One by one we learn the patient’s bizarre stories. The first story is of a young woman (Barbara Parkins) involved with a married man - he chops up his wife and puts her in a freezer. The young woman visits but finds the man in the freezer instead and she is attacked. The next story stars Peter Cushing as a customer of a tailor, he wants the tailor to make a suit for his dead son to be re-incarnated but the plans go array. The next patient is a delusional young girl (Charlotte Rampling) who has a split personality ‘Lucy’ (Britt Ekland) upon who she blames the murder of her brother and nurse. The final patient used to be a doctor and makes creepy robot models that have fully functioning brains and murderous intentions. Scary fun stuff with appropriate orchestral music to make sure you know when something weird is about to happen and the final twist reveals just who is Dr Starr.

results.title: AstroTurf
results.creator_credit: Magnetic Monster Video, Australian Film Commission, Rod Bishop and Ian Haig
results.material_description: Single channel moving image, colour and audio
results.brief_description: ‘AstroTurf’ is a 3-D animation that tours through periods of time that mark different technologies, from the prehistoric to beyond the 21st century. As the technology advances, human evolution is virtually at a standstill, always at odds with the technology that is demonstrated to be fallible. Ian Haig uses bold graphic style drawing on influences such as; 1950s television, sci-fi imagery, computer games, cartoons and comic books. ‘AstroTurf’ becomes a platform to celebrate computer imaging and the alternate aesthetics that the medium allows for.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Magnetic Monster Video, Australian Film Commission, Rod Bishop and Ian Haig

results.title: Astrology: strictly supernatural
results.creator_credit: Ludo Graham, Justin Hardy, Kaki Kirby, Stuart B Rekant, Non Fiction Films and Cafe Productions
results.brief_description: A fascinating introduction to the history and practice of Astrology. Includes interviews with astrologers talking about astrology and the history of astrology. By looking at the astrological charts of famous people (such as J.F. Kennedy and Ronald Reagan) we see how astrologers put together a chart then interpret it to give people valuable information about patterns in their life or behaviour. Explains how a the planets influence human life on Earth and how people have consulted with astrologers for over seven thousand years. Also considers the debate between traditional scientists and astrologers over the validity of Astrology as a science. Narrated by Christopher Lee.
